Borrower  Azerbaijan

Environment  The Project is classified as Category B. An initial environmental 
Assessment  examination was undertaken and the summary is in Appendix 12. 
   
Project Description  The  Project  has  four  components:  (i)  improvement  of 
127 kilometers (km) of two-lane paved road on the sections of 
Yevlakh–Ganja  and  Qazakh–Georgian  border  of  Azerbaijan’s 
primary east–west highway, (ii) improvement of 10 local roads 
totaling about 65 km in the project area, (iii) support for policy 
reform and improved governance in the road subsector through 
institutional strengthening, and (iv) facilitation of the movement 
across Azerbaijan’s border (at Red Bridge) with Georgia. 
   
Rationale  The  Project  is  a  priority  in  the  Government’s  transport 
development  program  (2005−2014).  The  Project  will  facilitate 
socioeconomic development by improving the east–west highway 
and local roads linking the western part of Azerbaijan closely to 
Baku,  the  country’s  capital;  and  increasing  local  communities’ 
access  to  markets,  job  opportunities,  and  social  services. 
The Project will also strengthen Azerbaijan’s transport links to 
Georgia and thus promote regional cooperation. As part of the 
Asian highway network and one of Azerbaijan’s main routes for 
external trade, the east–west highway carries traffic between the 
Caspian  and  Black  seas  and  has  the  potential  to  become  an 
important route for transit transport between Asia and Europe. 
The Project is included in ADB’s assistance program for 2005 and 
is consistent with its assistance strategy for Azerbaijan. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The  impact  of  the  Project  will  be  accelerated  socioeconomic 
development in the six rayons of west Azerbaijan and enhanced 
regional cooperation. The outcome will be increased traffic and 
improved  quality  and  efficiency  of  transport  on  the  east–west 
highway and selected local roads. 
   
Cost Estimates  The total project cost, including physical and price contingencies, 
interest, and other charges during construction, is estimated at 
$93.2 million equivalent.

Project Benefits and  The Project will benefit people living along the project sections of 
Beneficiaries  the  east–west  highway;  road  users;  construction  companies; 
traders;  and  other  people  who  derive  income  from  expanded 
traffic, trade, and investment in the project area. The major direct 
benefits  will  include  (i)  lower  road  transport  and  maintenance 
costs,  (ii)  faster  and  more  reliable  road  transport  services, 
(iii) improved access of local communities to markets and social 
services, (iv) job and income opportunities created during project 
implementation (i.e., use of local labor and construction materials) 
and  after  project  completion  (i.e.,  roadside  businesses), 
(v)  efficient  movement  of  freight  and  passengers  across 
Azerbaijan’s  border  (at  Red  Bridge)  with  Georgia,  and 
(vi)  strengthened  institutional  capacity  in  the  road  subsector. 
The economic internal rate of return for the Project is estimated at 
17.9%. The Project is expected to create 5,250 person-months of 
skilled  jobs  at  about  $400  per  person  per  month  and  3,000 
person-months of unskilled jobs at about $200 per person per 
month.  Indirect  benefits  will  be  increased  business  and  job 
opportunities  that  have  backward  or  forward  linkages  to  the 
Project, and expanded trade between Azerbaijan and Georgia as 
well as other countries in the region. 
   
Assumptions and Risks  The  Project  was  designed  based  on  the  following  key 
assumptions: (i) continued political stability and economic growth 
in  Azerbaijan  and  the  region,  (ii)  the  Government’s  continued 
commitment to regional cooperation, (iii) effective implementation 
of  the  Government’s  transport  development  program  (2005–
2014), (iv) timely provision of counterpart funding, and (v) timely 
cofinancing from IsDB and SFD. 
 
The Project’s major potential risk is that the project roads after 
completion  may  experience  a  higher  than  anticipated  rate  of 
deterioration due to axle overloading and inadequate funding for 
maintenance. Because the limited institutional capacity in the road 
subsector  constitutes  a  major  constraint  to  addressing  these 
issues,  the  Project  will  mitigate  this  risk  through  institutional 
strengthening assistance to the road subsector, accompanied by 
loan  conditionality.  The  Project  will  help  enforce  axle-load 
regulations by assisting RTSD to establish and operate vehicle 
weigh  stations  along  the  main  roads  and  improve  monitoring. 
During  project  preparation,  ADB  assisted  the  Government  in 
developing  a  road  maintenance  program,  which  envisages  a 
steady increase in maintenance funding to cover the entire road 
network by 2015. The Government is committed to implement the 
road  maintenance  program.  The  Project  will  support 
implementation of the program by assisting RTSD in reorganizing 
regional  maintenance  units,  prioritizing  roads  for  maintenance, 
utilizing the newly developed pavement management system, and 
identifying alternative sources for maintenance funding. Given the 
complexity of these issues, the Project is ADB’s first support for 
building effective institutions in Azerbaijan for sustainable road 
management  according  to  commercial  principals.  ADB  will 
continue assistance in this direction under future road projects.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans 
to the Republic of Azerbaijan for the East–West Highway Improvement Project. The design and 
monitoring framework of the Project is in Appendix 1. 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES1 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  Azerbaijan, with an area of about 86,600 square kilometer (km2) and population of  
8.3  million,  stands  at  the  crossroads  between  east  and  west  in  the  southern  Caucasus.  
The transport sector plays an important role in the national economy, accounting for 10.2% of 
gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  in  2003.  Roads  are  among  the  major  modes  of  transport. 
However,  road  transport  faces  challenges  due  to  the  country’s  transition  from  a  centrally 
planned to a market-oriented system. A detailed road subsector analysis is in Appendix 2.  
The significant features are summarized below. 
 
(i)  Azerbaijan  (excluding  Nakhchivan)2  has  a  road  network  of  about  18,800 
kilometers (km), comprising 4,577 km of national roads and 14,222 km of local 
roads. Road density is 0.2 km per km2. Approximately 52% of roads are paved, 
47% gravel, and the remaining earth tracks. About 75% of the network is in poor 
condition and needs rehabilitation. 
(ii)  In 2003 roads carried 78% of passengers in passenger-kilometers, 28% of freight 
in ton-kilometers, 29.8% of imports, and 6.9% of exports. 
(iii)  The use of motor vehicles is low by international standards. The vehicle fleet 
numbered  486,800  in  2003,  equivalent  to  58  vehicles  per  1,000  people.  
About 60% of vehicles are outdated and need to be replaced. 
(iv)  The  environment  for  road  transport  is  competitive,  with  the  private  sector 
accounting for more than 95% of freight and passenger transport in 2003. Almost 
all state-owned road transport operators have been privatized and foreign road 
transport operators are allowed to set up businesses. Freight charges and bus 
fares  for  domestic  transport  are  based  on  market  conditions,  while  the 
Government sets tariffs for cross-border and international transit vehicles. 
(v)  Roads are the responsibility of the Road Transport Service Department (RTSD) 
and the Auto Transport Service Department under the Ministry of Transport that 
was established in 2003. RTSD is responsible for road infrastructure networks, 
while the Auto Transport Service Department is responsible for road transport 
services. Institutional capacity in the subsector is limited. 
(vi)  With the abolishment of the Road Fund in 2001, roads are financed primarily 
from the Government’s budget. Although funding for road maintenance increased 
from AZM31.8 billion ($6.7 million) in 2001 to AZM153 million ($31.5 million) in 
2005, it accounted only for 0.2% of GDP and remained inadequate.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
3.  Road Network. Azerbaijan’s road network includes two major highways: the east–west 
highway linking Baku, the country’s capital, to the Georgian border and the north–south highway 
running from the Russian border to the Iranian border via Baku, as well as a number of 
secondary  and  local  roads.  The  east–west  highway,  which  is  about  500  km,  is  one  of 
Azerbaijan’s main routes for transport links to the western region and external trade. However, 
the network was developed primarily under the former Soviet Union when traffic volume was 
much higher. Due to lack of resources for maintenance and vehicle axle overloading, about 75% 
of the network is in poor condition. Based on the road condition data available, 61% of the east–
west and north–south highways, 76% of other national roads, 66% of secondary roads, and 
76% of rural roads require rehabilitation. This constitutes a major impediment to economic 
growth and private sector development due to high transport costs and accidents. In recognition 
of this, the Government has set improvement of road infrastructure as one of the priority actions 
in the State Programme on Poverty Reduction and Economic Development (SPPRED) for 
2003−20053 and embarked on a transport development program (2005–2014), which starts with 
improvement of the east–west and north–south highways. The Government is also finalizing a 
program for improving secondary roads. The majority of the east–west highway has been or is 
being  improved  with  external  assistance  (Table  1).  The  World  Bank-assisted  project  for 
improving the Ganja–Qazakh section is expected to be completed in 2006, while the European 
Bank of Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) is expected to complete improvement of the 
Hajigabul–Kyurdamir section in 2008. The proposed Asian Development Bank (ADB) Project 
will  improve  the  last  two  sections  of  the  east–west  highway  and  address  issues  on  road 
maintenance and vehicle axle overloading. This will help maximize the benefits from other 
improved sections of the highway so as to foster private sector-led economic growth.

4.  Road Maintenance. Azerbaijan inherited a large stock of road infrastructure from the 
former Soviet Union and is facing the challenge of properly maintaining the road network with 
limited resources. Based on the assumption that the entire road network is maintainable, RTSD 
estimates that total maintenance costs for 2005 are about $260 million. However, according to 
ADB staff assessment, road maintenance costs for 2005 amount to $37 million, partly because 
the unit rates are lower and partly because 25% of the network is estimated to be currently 
maintainable (Appendix 2). Funding for road maintenance increased from AZM31.8 billion ($6.7 
million) in 2001 to AZM153.0 billion ($31.5 million) in 2005, but remained inadequate. As a 
result, road maintenance operations are limited to emergency pavement repairs. Moreover, 
RTSD’s 61 rayon-based maintenance units, which currently undertake road maintenance works, 
are  inefficient  due  to  lack  of  economic  scale  and  weak  management.  In  recognition  that 
improved  roads  cannot  be  sustained  without  adequate  resources  to  maintain  them,  the 
Government plans to launch a road maintenance program in parallel with road improvement. 
The program envisages a steady increase in the maintainable network as road improvement 
takes place and a corresponding increase in maintenance funding to cover the entire network by 
2015. To implement the road maintenance program, the Government plans to reorganize the 
regional maintenance units and implement a newly developed pavement management system. 
Given that the limited institutional capacity in the road subsector constitutes a main constraint to 
implementing the road maintenance program, the Project will strengthen RTSD’s capacity for 
road  maintenance  by  helping  reorganize  regional  maintenance  units,  prioritize  roads  for 
maintenance, implement the pavement management system, and identify alternative sources of 
maintenance funding. 
 
5.  Axle-Load Control. Azerbaijan has developed regulations to limit vehicle axle load to  
13 tons, but enforcement is weak primarily due to limited institutional capacity and lack of 
vehicle weigh facilities. As a result, vehicle axle overloading is prevalent.4 Surveys conducted in 
1999 on the east–west highway showed that 20% of 4-axle trucks, 16% of 5-axle trucks, and 
13% of buses exceeded the axle-load limit. Heavy vehicle weights are one of the primary 
causes of rapid pavement deterioration and damage to bridges. In response, the Government 
recently decided to enforce axle-load regulations by establishing 12 vehicle weigh stations along 
main roads.5 The Project will assist RTSD in establishing and operating vehicle weigh stations, 
assessing the axle overloading problem, and improving monitoring of axle overloading. 
 
6.  Road Safety. Road accidents are increasing in Azerbaijan. The major causes include 
poor road conditions, lack of safety features and facilities, weak enforcement of road safety 
regulations,  intoxicated  driving,  and  inadequate  driver  education.  Although  the  State  Road 
Safety Commission is coordinating activities of concerned government agencies, it does not 
have executive powers. To improve road safety, the Government developed a road safety 
program that requires establishing road accident monitoring, reporting, and information systems. 
The Project will improve road safety by helping implement the road safety program; improve the 
legislation and regulations on road safety; develop road accident monitoring, reporting, and 
information systems; enhance RTSD’s capacity to identify accident black spots on the road 
network; and provide staff training. 
 
7.  Roads  and  Poverty  Reduction.  Despite  recent  economic  growth,  40.2%  of  the 
population in Azerbaijan was living in poverty in 2004. In the 6 rayons (regions)—Agstafa,

constraints on job opportunities. Improvement of road infrastructure is one of the priorities in the

highway and local roads, which will reduce transport costs for the poor in the project area and 
improve their access to jobs, markets, and basic social services. 
 
8.  Cross-Border and Transit Facilitation. The road system contributes significantly to 
cross-border and international transit traffic. The north–south highway connects the Russian 
Federation  and  Iran,  while  the  east–west  highway  is  Azerbaijan’s  segment  of  the  trans-
Caucasian corridor running between the Caspian and Black seas. The east–west highway also 
forms part of the Asian highway network6 and the “silk route” linking Asia to Europe. Although 
international traffic on the east–west highway is currently small (about 5% of the total traffic), the 
corridor has the potential to become an important transit route. Azerbaijan has signed a number 
of international transit and transport agreements and conventions. The country’s trade policy is 
generally liberal, with limited application of export tariffs for metals and articles, low import tariffs 
(a weighted average of 5.7% in 2004), and few quantitative restrictions.7 However, poor road 
conditions, inadequate border facilities, and limited capacity at Azerbaijan’s border with Georgia 
(at Read Bridge) are impeding cross-border traffic and trade. A World Bank survey shows that 
80% of firms experienced delays of 1−3 days in crossing the borders of Azerbaijan.8 Transport 
security has also become an emerging issue. The Project will facilitate the movement of freight 
and  passengers  across  the  border  of  Red  Bridge  by  improving  the  existing  cross-border 
agreement between Azerbaijan and Georgia, improving border facilities, providing equipment, 
and enhancing the capacity of officers serving at the border. 
 
9.  Institutional Capacity. Despite some improvement, institutional capacity in the road 
subsector remains inadequate. Officials have limited knowledge of sound sector policies and 
regulations needed for a market economy, management of commercially based road transport 
services,  new  technology  in  construction  and  maintenance  of  road  infrastructure,  and 
appropriate methodology for monitoring and evaluating road projects. During 2003–April 2005, 
the  World  Bank  extended  technical  assistance  for  institutional  strengthening  of  the  road 
subsector, which included (i) developing a corporate plan for RTSD, (ii) conducting a road 
inventory  and  functional  classification  of  the  network,  (iii)  reviewing  road  user  charges,  
(iv)  developing  a  pavement  management  system,  (v)  reviewing  technical  standards  and 
specifications,  (vi)  establishing  a  financial  management  system,  (vii)  developing  a  quality 
assurance  system,  (viii)  developing  a  multiyear  rolling  road  management  program,  
(ix) addressing traffic safety, and (x) assessing performance. The World Bank assistance is a 
first  step  toward  sustainable  road  development.  However,  the  subsector  needs  continued 
assistance, particularly with regard to the Government’s acceptance and implementation of 
World Bank recommendations. Based on the results of World Bank assistance, the Project will

10.  Governance and Corruption. Weak governance is a daunting challenge in Azerbaijan. 
The general perception in the private sector is that corruption exists and adversely affects 
sustainable development in the country. The Government has taken action to tackle corruption. 
The  new  Anticorruption  Law  became  effective  in  January  2005.  The  new  Anticorruption 
Commission  is  chaired  by  the  head  of  the  Presidential  Administration  and  comprises  
12 members from the Presidential Administration, Parliament, and constitutional courts. A new 
Procurement Law was adopted, which the World Bank considers as one of the better such laws 
in the region.10 The Government also adopted the State Program on Fight against Corruption for 
2004–2006  and  established  the  Special  Anticorruption  Department  within  the  Prosecutor’s 
Office in March 2005 to undertake corruption-related investigations. Work is also underway to 
ratify the United Nations Convention against Corruption. However, limited institutional capacity 
is a constraint on effective implementation of the law and the state program on anticorruption. 
The Project will improve governance in the road subsector by strengthening RTSD’s capacity for 
road maintenance, axle-load control, road safety, and project management and implementation. 
 
11.  Government  Strategy.  With  assistance  from  ADB  and  development  partners,  the 
Government  developed  the  SPPRED  for  2003–2005,  which  aims  to  reduce  poverty  and 
facilitate growth of employment and income. The Government is now preparing a new national 
poverty reduction strategy for 2006 onward. The Government also approved the State Program 
on Socioeconomic Development of Regions for 2004−200811 to promote regionally balanced 
development. In recognition of the importance of roads in poverty reduction and economic 
growth,  the  Government  developed  a  transport  development  program  (2005−2014).  
The  program  includes  (i)  improving  the  east–west  and  north–south  highways  by  2008,  
(ii) strengthening the institutional capacity of the transport sector, (iii) improving secondary and 
rural roads, and (iv) improving road maintenance. Given large funding requirements for road 
infrastructure  investments  and  the  limitation  of  mobilizing  private  sector  resources,  the 
Government has requested external aid agencies including ADB to help finance improvement of 
the main highways. The Government accords high priority to improving the east–west highway. 
The Project is highly relevant and responsive to Azerbaijan’s needs.

14.  Lesson Learned. Azerbaijan joined ADB in 1999 and ADB operations in the country are 
at an early stage, with two approved loans.15. Thus substantive lessons cannot be drawn from 
ADB operations in the country. However, the Project was designed with careful consideration of 
the lessons and experience of development partners in Azerbaijan and ADB’s similar projects in 
other transition economies. The following three lessons are particularly relevant. First, road 
infrastructure investments must be accompanied by effective policy dialogue and institutional 
strengthening to maximize development impact. Substantive policy dialogue on sector issues 
(e.g.,  road  maintenance,  axle-load  control,  and  road  safety)  was  conducted  during  project 
preparation and consequently strong policy content is included in the Project. Second, projects 
involving improvement of roads to borders should address cross-border issues, to the extent 
possible. The Project includes a component to address physical and institutional barriers at 
Azerbaijan’s border with Georgia at Red Bridge to facilitate cross-border movements. Third, 
RTSD staff has limited knowledge of operational policies and procedures of multilateral financial 
institutions including ADB, which resulted in prolonged negotiations on EBRD loans and an 
initial delay in implementing the World Bank-assisted road project. Close ADB supervision and 
provision  of  consulting  services  are  necessary  to  support  project  management  and  avoid 
implementation delays. Under the Project, substantive consulting services will be provided to 
help with project management and implementation. ADB will monitor project implementation 
closely through the executing agencies’ progress reports and its review missions.

C.  Special Features 
20.  Regional Cooperation. The Project will promote regional cooperation by improving 
Azerbaijan’s segment of the trans-Caucasian road corridor and the facilities at Azerbaijan’s 
border (Red Bridge) with Georgia, and enhancing the capacity of Azeri officers serving at the 
border. The east–west highway forms part of the Asian highway network and has the potential 
to  become  an  important  corridor  for  transit  traffic  between  Asia  and  Europe.  
The majority of this highway has been or is being improved with external assistance; the Project 
will improve the missing link of the highway. RTSD and the State Customs Committee will work 
together to implement the Project. Successful implementation of the Project will contribute to 
increasing traffic and trade among Azerbaijan, Georgia, and other countries in the region. 
 
21.  Policy  Dialogue  and  Institutional  Strengthening.  Investment  in  roads  should  be 
linked  to  a  strong  commitment  to  policy  reform  and  institution  building.  Given  that  road 
maintenance, axle loading, and road safety are the main road subsector issues in Azerbaijan, 
ADB  held  intensive  policy  dialogue  with  the  Government  on  these  issues  during  project 
preparation. ADB assisted the Government in developing a road maintenance program that 
envisages a gradual increase in maintenance funding to cover the entire road network by 2015. 
Because the limited institutional capacity in the road subsector constitutes a major constraint to 
addressing these issues, the Project includes a strong institutional strengthening component, 
which will enhance RTSD’s capacity for road maintenance, axle-load control, and road safety. 
This  component  will  supplement  road  infrastructure  investment  to  achieve  sustainable 
development. The Project is ADB’s first support for building effective institutions in Azerbaijan 
for sustainable road management based on commercial principals. ADB will continue assistance 
in this direction under future road projects.

extensive consultations with various stakeholders including representatives of central and local 
governments, civil society, local communities, the private sector, road users, and external aid

23.  Aid  Harmonization  of  Project  Implementation  Arrangements.  Aid-funded  road

training;  and  financing  for  staff,  equipment,  and  operating  expenses  needed  for  project 
implementation. This harmonized PIU structure will improve the efficiency of managing aid-
financed  projects,  facilitate  aid  coordination  on  project  implementation,  mitigate  the 
Government’s administrative resource constraints, and contribute to enhancing RTSD’s capacity

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Project Benefits 
40.  The Project will benefit people living along the Yevlakh–Ganja and Qazakh–Georgian 
border sections of the east–west highway; road users; construction companies; traders; and 
other people who derive income from expanded traffic, trade, and investment in the region.  
The major direct benefits will include (i) lower road transport and maintenance costs, (ii) faster 
and more reliable road transport services, (iii) improved access of local communities to markets 
and social services, (iv) jobs and income created during project implementation (i.e., use of local 
labor  and  construction  materials)  and  after  project  completion  (i.e.,  roadside  businesses),  
(v) efficient movement of freight and passengers across Azerbaijan’s border (at Red Bridge) 
with Georgia, and (vi) strengthened institutional capacity in the road subsector. The Project is 
expected to create 5,250 person-months of skilled jobs at about $400 per person per month and 
3,000 person-months of unskilled jobs at about $200 per person per month. Indirect benefits will 
be increased business and job opportunities that have backward or forward linkages to the 
Project, and growing trade among Azerbaijan, Georgia, and other countries in the region. 
 
41.  A distribution analysis shows that the Project will result in total net benefits of $71.8 
million, comprising $44.0 million for passengers, $11.6 million for freight operators, $15.9 million 
for the Government, and $0.3 million for labor. Road users (passengers and freight operators) 
are the largest beneficiary group, accounting for 77.5% of the total net project benefits. 
B.  Economic and Financial Analyses 
42.  Traffic forecasts were made for the project road for 2005−2028 based on the traffic 
surveys conducted during project preparation, projected growth of GDP and population, as well 
as the estimated income elasticity of demand. Based on economic and population growth 
projections, passenger traffic on the project road is forecast to grow annually by 7.8% for 
2005−2009 and 6.8% for 2010−2028, while freight traffic on the project road is projected to 
increase annually by 7.5% and 6.0% for the respective periods. These traffic forecasts are 
reasonable compared with actual annual growth of combined freight and passenger traffic 
during 1999–2005, which was 9.9% on the Yevlax–Ganja section and 9.5% on the Qazakh–
Georgian border section. 
 
43.  The economic analysis of the Project compares the with- and without-project cases and 
weights project benefits against project costs. The analysis is based on 2005 prices and covers 
24 years (2005−2028), comprising 4 years of project implementation and 20 years of operation 
(Appendix 9). The major project benefits are savings on vehicle operating cost and travel time 
due to reduced roughness on road surfaces. The benefits from vehicle operating cost savings, 
which initially accrue to vehicle owners and operators, will be shared gradually with passengers 
and freight customers through reduced freight charges and bus fares. The Project will contribute 
to reducing road accidents, but such benefits are not quantifiable and thus are not included in 
the economic analysis. The project costs cover capital investment and maintenance costs. 
 
44.  The results show that the Project is economically viable, with an economic internal rate 
of return (EIRR) of 17.9% and a net present value of $17.0 million at a 12% discount rate.

15 
The  sensitivity  analysis  confirms  the  Project’s  economic  viability,  with  the  EIRR  remaining 
higher than 12.0% when (i) capital investment costs increase by 20%, (ii) project benefits 
decrease by 20%, (iii) traffic growth declines by 20%, or (iv) both capital investment costs 
increase by 20% and project benefits decrease by 20%. The risk analysis demonstrates that  
(i) the Project’s EIRR has a 95 percentile value of 19.3% and a 5 percentile value of 15.5%, and 
(ii) the Project’s net present value has a 95 percentile value of $32.3 million and a 5 percentile 
value of $8.1 million. The risk analysis further confirms the Project’s economic robustness. 
 
45.  The  Project  is  not  a  revenue-earning  project  that  requires  a  financial  analysis.  
An analysis of the fiscal impact of the Project was made to assess counterpart funding for, and 
debt  repayment  from,  the  Project.  The  Government  has  committed  to  provide  counterpart 
funding of $19.8 million during project implementation. The external debt burden in Azerbaijan 
remains moderate, with the stock of public and publicly guaranteed debt at 18.6% of GDP and 
the debt service ratio at 3.7% in 2004. Given the projection of continued growth in Azerbaijan 
and resultant increase in government revenues over the medium term, the Government is very 
likely to provide counterpart funding in a timely manner and the Project will have a limited 
impact on the debt repayment situation in the country. The Project is thus deemed financially 
sustainable. 
C.  Project Impacts 
1.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement 
46.  The  Project  does  not  require  significant  land  acquisition  and  resettlement,  as  road 
improvement activities are largely confined to the existing alignment. Minor realignment may 
require land acquisition, but will have no impact on structures. Temporary land occupation for 
borrow  areas,  disposal  areas,  and  construction  camps  during  construction  will  require 
compensation for loss of crops or trees. In 2004, the Government initiated a national program to 
clear  structures  within  the  road  reserve.  For  the  project  road,  an  inventory  identified  
213 businesses and residences within the road reserve; 61 nontitled roadside businesses were 
removed along the Yevlakh–Ganja section. The owners of most of these businesses were 
aware that they would need to remove the businesses at their own expenses according to 
domestic  laws.  Local  authorities  and  RTSD  assisted  in  removing  these  businesses  and 
acquiring  land  plots  for  the  owners  to  build  permanent  shops.  So  far,  29  businesses  are 
operating in their new shops, 24 businesses are under construction, and 8 businesses are 
awaiting approval of land certificates. The businesses investigated by ADB staff during project 
preparation were satisfied with the removal procedures and the support received. 
 
47.  RTSD has prepared a resettlement plan, the first resettlement document for aid-financed 
road projects in Azerbaijan (supplementary appendix C). The summary resettlement plan is in 
Appendix 10. The resettlement plan provides the compensation standards and entitlements for 
affected land, housing, businesses, trees, attachments, and public infrastructure according to 
domestic laws and regulations as well as ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement. The plan 
includes retrofit measures for eligible businesses removed and measures for future resettlement 
impacts during the upgrading of the highway and local roads, and clearance of the road reserve. 
The plan was disclosed to local governments and affected people on 14 June 2005. RTSD 
agreed to suspend further demolition of structures from the road reserve until ADB approves the 
resettlement plan. When detailed design is completed in 2006, RTSD will update the plan, 
disclose it to those affected, and submit it for ADB approval prior to the commencement of civil 
works. The Ecology and Safety Section, Road Maintenance Division of RTSD is responsible for 
updating  the  resettlement  plan  and  supervising  its  implementation.  RTSD  will  engage  an

16   
independent  monitor  acceptable  to  ADB  to  carry  out  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  the 
resettlement impacts during project implementation. 
2.  Poverty Reduction, Social, and Gender Impacts 
48.  The Project will benefit about 261,000 poor people (37.2% of total project beneficiaries) 
in the project area; the total benefits to be received by the poor are estimated at $7.1 million. 
Although the project benefits for the poor are relatively small, the Project will create an enabling 
environment for poverty reduction. The major poverty reduction impacts of the Project will 
include (i) reduced prices of transport services, food, and other daily necessities due to lower 
transport costs; (ii) jobs and income for the poor in road improvement and maintenance as well 
as roadside businesses; and (iii) improved access of the poor to markets and social services.  
A summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 11. 
 
49.  The Project has no impact on indigenous peoples. Ethnic Azeri accounts for 98.6% of 
the population in the project area; few other nationalities include Kurds, Russian, and Turks.  
The minorities are neither indigenous nor negatively affected by the Project. The Project will 
have a positive impact on gender, because the civil works contracts will include provisions to 
encourage employment of women during project implementation, and the Project will promote 
women’s participation in activities to monitor project impacts on local communities. 
 
50.  In 2004, 718 HIV/AIDS20 cases (including 38 cases in the project area) were reported. 
Construction workers, truck drivers, sex workers, and intravenous drug users are among the 
groups  at  high  risks  of  HIV  infection.  The  International  Medical  Corp  is  implementing  an 
HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention program in the project area, which includes (i) training to 
local  communities,  truck  drivers,  doctors,  and  nurses;  (ii)  condom  distribution;  and  
(iii) improvement of local health facilities. All civil works bidding documents and contracts under 
the Project will include provisions requiring contractors to take measures to protect construction 
workers and local residents, especially women, from potential risks of HIV/AIDS and other 
sexually transmitted infections. These measures include raising public awareness of the risks of 
HIV/AIDS and other sexually transmitted infections, and giving construction workers time to be 
tested or receive treatment. 
 
51.  The Project includes appropriate measures to mitigate the potential risk of drug and 
human trafficking. The provision of inspection equipment at the border of Red Bridge and 
capacity building for officers serving at the border will greatly assist in preventing drug and 
human trafficking. The roadside stations that will be included in the detailed project design will 
offer  a  venue  for  advocacy  and  awareness  campaigns  on  prevention  of  drug  and  human 
trafficking in the future. ADB is undertaking a study on HIV/AIDS and human trafficking in 
Azerbaijan. Based on the findings, ADB will consider an appropriate modality of assistance. 
3.  Environmental Impact 
52.  The Project is classified as Category B. An initial environmental examination (IEE) was 
undertaken (supplementary appendix D) and the summary IEE is in Appendix 12. The IEE 
concludes that the Project will have no major adverse impacts on the environment, as road 
improvement will be primarily carried out on the existing alignment. Minor realignments may be 
made within the road reserve to ensure the horizontal radii and forward sight distances are 
suitable for the designed speed. Temporary use of land adjacent to the project road, removal of

extraction and transport of construction material from borrow sites will have temporary impacts

archaeological importance are within or near the project area. 
 
53.  The mitigation measures identified in the IEE include (i) carefully selecting construction 
sites, borrow areas, and quarries and restoring them soon after project completion; (ii) avoiding 
aggravation of soil erosion-prone areas; (iii) controlling sewage discharge and other waste fluids 
from construction sites, and hazardous and toxic materials from asphalt and crushing plants and 
from  construction  equipment;  (iv)  maintaining  proper  drainage  to  avoid  stagnation  and 
controlling downstream water pollution; (v) reinstating vegetation and trees that are affected by 
construction activities but are needed to prevent soil erosion; (vi) controlling disturbances to 
animals  and  pastures;  and  (vii)  minimizing  noise,  dust,  emissions,  and  other  pollutants 
associated with civil works. The civil works contractors will take these mitigation measures, 
while the supervision consultant, RTSD, and concerned government environmental agencies 
will monitor their implementation. 
D.  Project Assumptions and Risks 
54.  The Project was designed based on the following key assumptions: (i) continued political 
stability and economic growth in Azerbaijan and the region, (ii) the Government’s continued 
commitment to regional cooperation, (iii) effective implementation of the Government’s transport 
development program (2005–2014), (iv) timely provision of counterpart funding, and (v) timely 
cofinancing from IsDB and SFD. 
 
55.  The  Project’s  major  potential  risk  is  that  the  project  roads  after  completion  may 
experience  a  higher  than  anticipated  rate  of  deterioration  due  to  axle  overloading  and 
inadequate  funding  for  maintenance.  Because  the  limited  institutional  capacity  in  the  road 
subsector constitutes a major constraint to addressing these issues, the Project will mitigate this 
risk through institutional strengthening assistance to the road subsector, accompanied by loan 
conditionality. The Project will help enforce axle-load regulations by assisting RTSD to establish 
and operate vehicle weigh stations along the main roads and improve monitoring. During project 
preparation, ADB assisted the Government in developing a road maintenance program, which 
envisages a steady increase in maintenance funding to cover the entire road network by 2015. 
The Government is committed to implementing the road maintenance program. The Project will 
support implementation of the program by assisting RTSD in reorganizing regional maintenance 
units, prioritizing roads for maintenance, utilizing the newly developed pavement management 
system, and identifying alternative sources for maintenance funding. Given the complexity of 
these issues, the Project is ADB’s first support for building effective institutions in Azerbaijan for 
sustainable road management according to commercial principals. ADB will continue assistance 
in this direction under future road projects.

ROAD SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 
A.  Background 
1.  Azerbaijan occupies a key location in the regional transport network of the southern 
Caucasus. The country’s east–west road and railway routes carry traffic between the Caspian 
and  Black  seas  on  a  section  of  the  “silk  road”  transport  corridor  linking  Asia  to  Europe.  
The  country’s  north–south  road  and  rail  routes  connect  the  Russian  Federation  and  Iran.  
The transport sector plays an important role in the national economy, accounting for 10.2% of 
gross domestic product (GDP) in 2003. 
 
2.  Like other sectors, Azerbaijan’s roads are facing the challenges of the transition from a 
centrally planned to a market-based economy. Although many good laws, regulations, and 
procedures are in place, the major challenge is related to implementing. In this regard, a 
number of issues need to be addressed, particularly in the areas of road maintenance, axle-load 
control, and road safety. 
 
B.  Transport Demand 
3.  The transport sector comprises railways, roads, air aviation, sea transport, pipelines, and 
urban transport. The demand for freight and passenger transport by mode is shown in Table 
A2.1.  Freight  transport  demand  increased  at  an  annual  average  rate  of  11.6%  during 
2000−2003. Freight demand was mainly met by railways (35%), followed by sea transport 
(30%), and roads (28%). Although the volume of freight transport carried by railways is greater 
than by roads, fundamental differences in type of freight carried result in limited opportunity for 
competition and modal shift between railways and roads. The major freight carried by railways is 
crude  oil  and  refined  oil  products  from  Baku.  While  this  is  expected  to  continue  in  the 
foreseeable future, crude oil will be partially transported through the recently opened Baku–
Tbilisi–Ceyhan oil pipeline. Moreover, freight demand for road transport grew by 21% annually 
during 2000−2003, more rapidly than for other modes of transport. The potential for growth in 
freight demand for road transport is significant. As transport demand becomes more diversified, 
specific features such as speed, reliability, waiting time, minimization of losses and damages, 
and ability to move smaller loads more efficiently will assume greater priority than they did in the 
past.  These  features  will  require  flexible,  cost-effective,  and  responsive  transport  services.  
Road transport is better placed than other modes of transport to meet these needs by providing 
efficient services and infrastructure needed to facilitate expected growth. 
 
4.  Passenger transport has grown steadily since 2000; demand is recovering from the low 
points experienced in the late 1990s. Roads are the dominant mode of transport, accounting for 
nearly 80% of passenger transport. Civil aviation accounts for 9%, urban transport for 8%, and 
railways for 7% of the total demand. While the modal share between road and rail transport may 
be distorted by the overwhelming use of roads for short-distance urban trips, with continued 
economic growth demand for passenger transport by roads is expected to increase because 
local  and  regional  buses  provide  a  quicker  and  more  convenient  services  than  railways, 
particularly to intermediate locations. With the improvement of the east–west and north–south 
highways, bus transport operators are expected to provide new buses that will improve services 
and increase the modal share of road transport.

E.  Road Subsector Institutions 
8.  Presidential Decree No. 299 issued in March 2000 on the application of the Law of 
Roads  of  December  1999  defines  the  general  basis  for  design,  construction,  operation, 
maintenance,  and  development  of  roads  and  associated  structures  as  well  as  the  legal, 
technical, economic, and institutional principles for road management. The decree also outlines 
the basic relations between stakeholders in the road subsector. 
 
9.  Prior to 2003, Azeravtoyol, a state joint stock company, managed the road subsector. 
Azeravtoyol was formed in 1993 and modeled around centralized decision-making processes, 
bureaucracy, and administration procedures inherited from the former Soviet Union. Because 
the  organization  was  weak  and  could  not  perform  its  functions  properly,  the  Government 
dissolved Azeravtoyol and in 2003 established the Ministry of Transport to assume overall 
responsibility  for  policy,  regulations,  and  administration  of  the  transport  sector.  The  road 
subsector falls under the responsibility of two departments of the Ministry of Transport: Road 
Transport  Service  Department  (RTSD)  and  Auto  Transport  Service  Department.  RTSD  is 
responsible for planning, managing, and maintaining the road network infrastructure. RTSD has 
a headquarters unit in Baku with 90 staff and 61 regional units with approximately 3,000 staff, 
primarily responsible for individual rayons. An organization structure of RTSD headquarters is in 
Figure  A2.  The  Auto  Transport  Service  Department  is  responsible  for  formulating  and 
implementing regulations on passenger and freight transport services, including (i) intercity 
passenger services, (ii) freight transport services, (iii) foreign vehicles entering and leaving 
Azerbaijan, (iv) vehicle emission requirements, and (v) coordination with transport ministries in 
other countries. 
 
10.  The creation of RTSD to replace Azeravtoyol is a major achievement. RTSD received 
assistance from the World Bank for institutional strengthening during 2003–April 2005. This 
program covered 11 areas, with the major components including (i) developing a corporate plan, 
(ii)  reviewing  road  user  charges,  (iii)  establishing  a  pavement  management  system,  
(iv) formulating a financial management system, (v) developing a multiyear rolling budget, and

F.  Financial Management 
11.  Prior to 2001, roads were financed primarily through the Road Fund created in 1994.  
All revenues collected from taxes related to roads were credited to the Road Fund during that 
period. Since the abolition of the Road Fund in 2001, all revenues from taxes related to roads 
have been credited to government budgets. Currently three taxes are involved: transit fees (on 
foreign vehicles), annual vehicle tax, and fuel tax.  
 
12.  Road expenses are financed primarily by the Government through budgetary allocation 
to  RTSD.  RTSD’s  total  expenses  for  2003  amounted  to  AZM93.0  billion  ($19.2  million), 
comprising AZM70.0 billion ($14.5 million) for capital and recurrent expenditures and AZM23.0 
billion ($4.7 million) for salaries and administrative expenses at headquarters. However, no 
financial audit has been undertaken to assess the effectiveness of RTSD’s use of the funds. 
The Azerbaijan Accounting Chamber, the Government audit office, scheduled an audit of RTSD 
in 2005. 
 
13.  RTSD’s financial management capacity is limited due to the scarcity of experienced 
human  resources,  inadequate  staff  training,  and  lack  of  a  computer-based  management 
information  system.  In  recognition  of  this,  RTSD  proposes  a  reorganization  involving  the 
establishment of four regional offices and bringing all local offices under the proposed regional 
offices. RTSD’s proposed structural changes are waiting for Ministry of Transport approval.

I.  Vehicle Axle-Load Control 
24.  Although Azerbaijan has developed regulations to limit vehicle axle load to 13 tons, 
enforcement is weak due to limited institutional capacity and lack of weigh facilities. Vehicle 
weigh stations have not been established along the main roads, and government officials do not 
have  appropriate  training  and  equipment  for  monitoring  and  enforcement  of  axle-load 
regulations. As a result, vehicle axle overloading is prevalent. Surveys conducted in 1999 on the 
east–west highway showed that 20% of 4-axle trucks, 16% of 5-axle trucks, and 13% of buses 
exceeded the axle-load limit. Heavy vehicle weights are one of the primary causes of rapid 
pavements deterioration and damage to bridges. The recently reconstructed Alyat–Haciqabul 
section of the east–west highway shows serious pavement damage in a number of spots.  
The  enforcement  of  vehicle  axle-load  control  is  urgently  needed  to  prevent  premature 
deterioration of the road network. 
 
25.  In  response,  the  Government  recently  decided  to  enforce  axle-load  regulations  by  
(i) establishing 12 vehicle weigh stations along main roads, where overloaded vehicles will be 
required to redistribute or unload exceeded freight; and (ii) collecting reliable data on vehicle 
axle  loads by  installing  permanent  “weigh-in-motion”  devices at  key  points  along  the  road 
network. This will help quantify the overloading problem and assess the effectiveness of weight 
bridges.  The  ADB-assisted  East–West  Highway  Improvement  Project  will  assist  RTSD  in 
establishing and operating vehicle weigh stations, assess the axle overloading problem, and 
improve monitoring of axle overloading. 
 
J.  Road Transport Services 
26.  The environment for road transport services is competitive in Azerbaijan. The private 
sector plays a key role in provision of road transport services, accounting for more than 95% of 
freight and passenger transport in 2003. The state-owned road transport operators were largely 
privatized  and  foreign  road  transport  operators  are  allowed  to  set  up  their  businesses.  
Freight charges and bus fares for domestic road transport are determined based on market 
conditions,  though  the  Government  sets  tariffs  for  cross-border  and  international  transit 
vehicles. No vehicle licensing has been required since September 2003, but the Government 
plans to introduce it within 2005 to enhance axle-load control and improve road safety.

B.  Economic Analysis 
4.  The economic analysis of the Project covers 2005−2028, comprising 4 years of road 
improvement and 20 years of operation. It was based on a comparison of with- and without-
project cases and the weight of project benefits against project costs. It uses 2005 economic 
prices and the border price numeraire. 
 
5.  The project costs comprise capital investment and road maintenance costs, excluding 
taxes. Capital investment costs are based on the actual prices in the recently awarded civil 
works contracts for improving other sections with similar conditions of the east–west highway. 
The project costs were divided into tradable materials and equipment, nontradable materials, 
and labor. They were converted into economic values based on the estimated taxes under the 
recently awarded similar civil works contracts and using a standard conversion factor of 0.983 
for nontradable inputs. The economic costs for road improvement average $487,000 per km, 
while road maintenance costs per km after project completion are estimated at $900 for annual

E.  Environmental Monitoring and Institutional Requirement 
7.  An  environmental  management  and  monitoring  plan  was  prepared  to  mitigate  the 
potential environmental impacts of the Project. During construction, environmental monitoring 
will ensure the protection of embankments from potential soil erosion, borrow pits restoration, 
quarry  activities,  location  of  work  sites  and  material  storages,  location  of  asphalt  plants, 
preservation  of  religiously  sensitive  locations,  community  relations,  and  safety  provisions. 
During operation, air, noise, and surface water quality monitoring and greening and landscaping 
of project roads will be important parameters of the monitoring program. In cooperation with the 
project implementation unit and the Ecology and Safety Unit, the supervision consultant during 
project implementation will be required to (i) develop an environmental auditing protocol for the 
construction  period  and  formulate  a  detailed  monitoring  and  management  plan;  and  
(ii) supervise the civil works for road improvement and submit quarterly reports based on the 
monitoring data and laboratory analysis report. The cost for environmental monitoring during 
construction and operation is estimated at $636,000. 
 
8.  The agencies involved in executing and monitoring the environmental aspects of the 
Project  include  the  Ecology  and  Safety  Unit  of  RTSD  responsible  for  managing  the 
environmental impacts, greening, and landscaping of national roads; RTSD’s district offices; and 
MENR.  The  design  consultant  will  be  responsible  for  incorporating  the  environmental 
management and monitoring plan into engineering design and the supervision consultant will 
undertake  environmental  monitoring  during  construction.  The  supervision  consultant  will 
supervise  monitoring  of  mitigation  measures  during  construction.  The  contractors  will  be 
responsible  for  subcontracting  data  collection  of  environmental  monitoring  to  a  recognized 
organization. Each contractor will be required to nominate an environmental, health, and safety 
specialist  responsible  for  meeting  the  contractors’  environmental,  health,  and  social 
responsibilities. 
 
F.  Stakeholder Consultation and Information Disclosure 
9.  The  IEE  process  included  stakeholder  participation  and  consultation  to  help  RTSD 
achieve public acceptance of the Project. In October 2004 and February 2005, stakeholder 
consultations were conducted in Baku, Borsunlu, Delimemmedly, Ganja, Goranboy, Qazakh, 
and Yevlakh), which involved a wide range of participants (over 150 people) representing the 
Government; nongovernment organizations; scientific, education, and health institutions; civil 
society; businesses; and media. The consultation process was documented according to ADB’s 
and  the  Government’s  requirements  and  the  recommendations  were  incorporated  in  the 
preliminary design of the Project. The results of the consultations were positive, with people 
considering  that  the  Project  will  bring  significant  economic  benefits  to  the  region  and  will 
increase trade flows. Major concerns were related to damage of local roads during construction, 
enforcement of speed limits, intersection improvement, street lighting, proper traffic signs and 
pedestrian crossings, involvement of local people during construction, and quick implementation 
of the Project.

G.  Conclusion 
10.  The IEE reveals that no major negative environmental impacts are likely to occur during 
project implementation and operation after project completion. Recommendations are included 
in an environmental monitoring and management plan to mitigate expected negative impacts 
identified in the IEE and adequate funds will be provided for this purpose. 
 
11.  The Project will have overall beneficial impacts through better accessibility for cross-
border traffic connecting to the Georgian border, increased trade flows in the region, reduced 
travel time, reduced dust, and improved road safety. Rehabilitation of local roads will also 
enhance  access  of  poor  villages  to  markets,  schools,  health  care  facilities,  and  job 
opportunities.
